entry.title: Proof-of-Stake Bitcoin Sidechains
entry.summary:
The email from ZmnSCPxj to Matt Bell discusses an innovative approach to integrating a proof-of-mainstake sidechain with the Bitcoin mainchain without necessitating any modifications to the latter. The core idea revolves around conceptualizing a blockchain as a minimalistic Merklized singly-linked list where each block header acts as a node, linking to its predecessor and encapsulating the block data. This foundational concept is paralleled in the proposed sidechain design, where a chain of single-input single-output transactions forms the sidechain "blockchain." These transactions are uniquely linked through the expenditure of the previous transaction's output and may also commit to arbitrary data, akin to how block headers commit to preceding headers and block content.
A critical aspect underscored is the limitation imposed by Bitcoin's scripting language on the number of non-push operations and, by extension, the number of signatories for sidechain funds within the mainchain. This presents a significant challenge in managing the sidechain funds, which ideally should be consolidated into a single UTXO to simplify deposits and withdrawals while adhering to the sidechain's rules.
To bridge mainchain and sidechain interactions, two primary mechanisms are detailed: requests for staking coins to the sidechain and transferring coins from the mainchain to the sidechain. These processes involve creating mainchain transactions that spend the sidechain's UTXO, incorporating the new stakes or transfers, thereby generating a new sidechain UTXO reflective of the updated signatory set. Notably, the design includes safeguards allowing stakeholders to recover their funds should their requests be overlooked, leveraging a dual-branch script structure for both staking and transfer indications.
The email elaborates on operational nuances, such as handling fees and ensuring the prompt confirmation of sidechain managing transactions on the mainchain. The possibility of maintaining a more rapid or consistent block rate for the sidechain relative to the mainchain is explored, suggesting the maintenance of an internal "real" blockchain within the sidechain, with managing transactions committing to the latest agreed-upon sidechain block header. This approach requires a coordinated effort among stakers to create and, if necessary, replace sidechain managing transactions using Replace-By-Fee (RBF) to accommodate for delays in mainchain confirmations.
This proposed framework showcases a novel method of embedding a sidechain within Bitcoin's existing infrastructure, aiming to enhance functionality and interoperability without compromising the integrity or security of the mainchain.
